title: Using Phonemes in cascaded S2S translation pipeline
author: Rene Pilz (University of Liechtenstein), Johannes Schneider (University of Liechtenstein)
background: This paper investigates the effectiveness of using phonemic representations within a speech-to-speech translation pipeline, particularly for translations between English and German.
contribution: This paper introduces a phonemic approach in sequence-to-sequence translation to solve challenges associated with low-resource languages, achieving comparable quality to traditional text-based methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Conventional translation methods depend heavily on written language forms and require extensive data for training, limiting their applicability to under-resourced languages.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances existing translation frameworks by evaluating the efficacy of phonemic representations across the entire process, not just during input.

key_innovation: The integration of phonemic representations throughout the S2S pipeline simplifies the translation process, particularly benefiting low-resource languages by reducing computational requirements.
real_world_impact: The findings potentially improve real-time translation quality in multilingual communications, especially in regions with limited resources or no official written languages. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The study highlights limitations in semantic understanding of the model, which affect all translations regardless of the representation used.

new_terms.phonemic representation: **Phonemic representation** refers to the abstract representations of phonemes in speech that can be used to improve speech processing tasks like translation and synthesis.

open_sourcing: Research outputs are publicly available at https://github.com/fungus75/Phonemes_S2S_Pipeline
